howToChooseGPU.title: How to choose the right gas piston unit (GPU)
howToChooseGPU.intro1: Gas piston units (GPUs) are an effective solution for autonomous power supply, reducing electricity costs, and increasing business energy independence.
howToChooseGPU.intro2: However, to select the optimal GPU, it’s important to consider many technical parameters and the characteristics of the site where it will be installed. In this article, we’ll break down what to focus on when choosing a gas piston unit to ensure maximum efficiency and reliability.

parameter1.title: 1. Determining power and operating mode
parameter1.description: Before purchasing a GPU, it’s essential to accurately calculate the facility’s power consumption and select a unit with matching specifications.
parameter1.point1: What is the peak and average daily load at the facility?
parameter1.point2: Will the GPU be used as the primary or backup energy source?
parameter1.point3: Is it necessary to consider the possibility of parallel operation with multiple units?
parameter1.tip: If the unit will be the primary energy source, choose a GPU with a 10-15% power reserve to account for load. If it will work in parallel with the grid or as a backup, you can calculate power more precisely based on critical loads.

parameter2.title: 2. Fuel efficiency and gas consumption
parameter2.description: GPU efficiency is measured by electrical efficiency, thermal efficiency, and total efficiency (cogeneration). Higher efficiency means lower operating costs.
parameter2.point1: Electrical efficiency (%) – shows how much gas energy is converted into electricity. Good models achieve 38-46%.
parameter2.point2: Thermal efficiency (%) – if heat utilization is planned, thermal efficiency matters (typically 40-48%).
parameter2.point3: Total efficiency (%) – with combined electricity and heat production (cogeneration), efficiency can reach 90% or more.
parameter2.point4: Gas consumption – measured in m³/MW of electricity and affects the cost of electricity.
parameter2.tip: Choose a unit with maximum total efficiency (e.g., Jenbacher, MWM, Bergen, Wärtsilä) for cogeneration solutions. If heat isn’t used, focus on electrical efficiency.

summary.title: Summary: How to choose the optimal gas piston unit?
summary.point1: Calculate the required power and determine the operating mode (primary/backup).
summary.point2: Assess operating conditions and site specifics for GPU placement: availability of electrical and gas infrastructure, as well as required space.
summary.point3: Compare efficiency and fuel consumption across different models.
summary.point4: Consider operating life and maintenance intervals.
summary.point6: Check availability of service support in your region.
summary.point7: Choose between GPU or CHP if cogeneration is needed.
summary.conclusion: The right choice of a gas piston unit ensures reliable power supply, minimizes fuel and maintenance costs, and accelerates investment payback.

brands.title: Popular manufacturers
brands.jenbacher: Austrian manufacturer, a market leader. Jenbacher is renowned for high reliability and adaptability to various gas types (natural gas, biogas, landfill gas, mine gas, and even hydrogen blends). The units offer one of the highest efficiencies on the market – up to 90% in cogeneration, making them an excellent choice for industry and utilities. However, the high equipment cost requires careful payback calculation.
brands.mwm: German brand with a 150-year history. MWM offers units with optimized fuel consumption, reducing operating costs. High automation and remote monitoring. Premium segment with a high price.
brands.mtu: German manufacturer of premium solutions (Rolls-Royce). Modular units for hybrid systems. Ideal for facilities with high reliability demands. Downsides – frequent maintenance and expensive parts.
brands.cat: American industrial giant. CAT GPU advantages include a wide service network, parts availability, and high power. However, efficiency and performance lag behind European counterparts, with above-average fuel consumption.
brands.bergen: Norwegian brand of large units. Known for enhanced reliability and long engine life (up to 100,000 hours). Downsides: high cost and complex service.
brands.wartsila: Finnish manufacturer for large-scale generation. Flexible with various fuel types. High efficiency and durability. Downsides: high price and service complexity.
brands.cummins: American manufacturer of affordable and reliable GPUs. Simple design and parts availability. Lags behind European brands in efficiency and service life, with higher fuel consumption.
brands.doosan: South Korean corporation, popular in Asia and Eastern Europe. Affordable price and good performance. Shorter service life until overhaul and lower efficiency than premium brands.
brands.himoinsa: Spanish brand of compact and mobile GPUs. Suitable for small facilities and backup power. Relatively short service life and lower efficiency.
brands.gentec: Manufacturer of mid-range GPUs with flexible customization. Service support is limited compared to major brands.
brands.mitsubishi: Japanese manufacturer with innovative solutions. Enhanced reliability, long service life, and efficiency. Downsides: high cost and service complexity.

programs.title: Distributed generation strategy in Ukraine
programs.paragraph1: Ukraine is rapidly developing a distributed generation program, which involves installing independent energy sources directly at enterprises and communities. Gas piston units (GPUs) play a key role as an efficient and reliable solution for producing electricity and heat.
programs.paragraph2: GPUs reduce reliance on centralized grids, cut energy costs, and ensure energy independence during peak loads or crises. The government supports this direction through regulatory mechanisms and incentives for businesses to adopt local generation sources, especially relevant amid energy system instability.
